p.s: Description of Dactylosporangium fulvum sp. nov.
Dactylosporangium fulvum (ful'vum. L. neut. adj. fulvum yellowish brown, referring to the color of the vegetative mycelium)

The formation of finger-shaped sporangia containing motile spores, the absence of true aerial mycelia, and the presence of type II cell walls place strain SF-2113T in the genus Dactylosporangium Thiemann, Pagani, and Beretta (20).
Five species, D. aurantiacum (20), D. thailandense (19, 20), D. matsuzakiense (16), D. vinaceum (17), and D. ruseum, (14), were described previously as members of the genus Dactylosporangium.
We compared strain SF-2113T directly with type strains of these species.
The morphology of the finger-shaped sporangia and the spores did not differ significantly from that of any of the known species.
In addition to finger-shaped sporangia, the formation of globose bodies was proposed as an additional morphological characteristic of the genus Dactylosporangium (20).
Sharples and Williams (11) reported that the globose bodies seemed to be products of abnormal development, induced by bacteriophage infection or other factors which cause hyphal lysis.
Strain SF-2113T produced globose bodies abundantly.

Among the known species, D. aurantiacum and D. thailandense produced globose bodies as abundantly as strain SF-2113T, whereas the other three species either did not produce them or produced them sparsely (Table 2).
Furthermore, strains SF-2113T formed coremia abundantly.
The formation of coremia, also called synnemata, have been reported for various genera of the order Actinomycetales.
Although the taxonomic significance of coremia is not clear, their formation is an important characteristic in the genus Actinosynnema (4).
Strain SF-2113T formed abundant coremia regularly on oatmeal agar and inorganic salts-starch agar.
None of the other five species formed coremia on these media (Table 2).
With respect to coremia formation, therefore, strain SF-2113T differs from the known species.

Furthermore, strain SF-2113T differs clearly from the five other species in its cultural and physiological characteristics, as described below. D. vinaceum produced a wine to deep red diffusible pigment on almost all of the media used, whereas strain SF-2113T did not produce an obvious diffusible pigment on any of the same media. D. roseum showed a distinctive rose reverse color on yeast extract-malt extract agar (ISP medium 2), inorganic salts-starch agar, and especially on sucroseyeast extract agar, whereas the reverse color of strain SF-2113T was yellowish brown to brown on these media.
The distinctive reverse color of D. aurantiacum, D. thailandense, and D. matsuzakiense was orange, whereas strain SF-2113T never showed orange color on any of the media used.
In addition, strain SF-2113T differed from these three species in some physiological properties, such as the utilization of L-rhamnose and the production of antibiotic (Table 2).
In view of the characteristics described above, strain SF-2113T should be considered a new species of the genus Dactylosporangium, for which we propose the name Dactylosporangium fulvum sp. nov.
Strain SF-2113 is the type strain of D. fulvum; a culture of this strain has been deposited in the Institute for Fermentation, Osaka, Japan, as strain IFO 14381.
